channel.title: Comments on: Monday Go Meditation: Game 22

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Well I thought you played a fantastic game. I'm going to have to up my game if I'm to keep up with you! =D
item.content:encoded: Well I thought you played a fantastic game. I’m going to have to up my game if I’m to keep up with you! =D

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: You're right. I really should not have given you so much power with that invasion. Haha. Poor decision on my part...
item.content:encoded: You’re right. I really should not have given you so much power with that invasion. Haha. Poor decision on my part…

item.title: By: Nate Eagle
item.dc:creator: Nate Eagle
item.description: For me, your invasion at c17 was the crucial moment in the opening. It completely solved my potential problems on the top and put me in a position to attack, the benefits of which really lasted the whole game. An attack like g17 instead might have changed the whole game.
item.content:encoded: For me, your invasion at c17 was the crucial moment in the opening. It completely solved my potential problems on the top and put me in a position to attack, the benefits of which really lasted the whole game. An attack like g17 instead might have changed the whole game.

item.title: By: Nate Eagle
item.dc:creator: Nate Eagle
item.description: I agree with Moboy78 that move 33 wasn't slack. It was a strong attack, and my cut in response was probably premature. I'm pleased (I have to admit) that my kakari at R14 troubled you - it was my attempt to put Shifu's comments about its purpose into practice. But that's easier said than done. It's one thing to say that black's development is flat, but another to take advantage of it. (Note: my attempts to try out things from workshop often end disastrously.) I have felt recently, though, that my attempt to have faith in strong positions, thickness, and whole board development have been producing results. It still comes as a surprise to me - where did that territory come from? But I feel like I'm really getting away from being such a fixedly territorial player and it's helping me move forward. That said, I had to fight my feeling about how big your right side was the whole game.
item.content:encoded:
I agree with Moboy78 that move 33 wasn’t slack. It was a strong attack, and my cut in response was probably premature.
I’m pleased (I have to admit) that my kakari at R14 troubled you – it was my attempt to put Shifu’s comments about its purpose into practice. But that’s easier said than done. It’s one thing to say that black’s development is flat, but another to take advantage of it. (Note: my attempts to try out things from workshop often end disastrously.)
I have felt recently, though, that my attempt to have faith in strong positions, thickness, and whole board development have been producing results. It still comes as a surprise to me – where did that territory come from? But I feel like I’m really getting away from being such a fixedly territorial player and it’s helping me move forward.
That said, I had to fight my feeling about how big your right side was the whole game.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Ohhhhhh.... Excellent point. I didn't really notice that White was behind enemy lines... Definitely a great distinction. Thanks for clarifying!
item.content:encoded: Ohhhhhh…. Excellent point. I didn’t really notice that White was behind enemy lines… Definitely a great distinction. Thanks for clarifying!

item.title: By: Moboy78
item.dc:creator: Moboy78
item.description: Hey Ben, on move 33, when you said you thought you wasted a move attacking him, you really didn't. When you draw a line from q10 to k11, you see that white's group doesn't quite poke out from behind that line. If white wants his group to be secure from attack, he has get out from behind enemy lines. If he doesn't, it becomes black's game to win. With this in mind, your move wasn't a "non-threatening attack", but a good move instead =).
item.content:encoded: Hey Ben, on move 33, when you said you thought you wasted a move attacking him, you really didn’t. When you draw a line from q10 to k11, you see that white’s group doesn’t quite poke out from behind that line. If white wants his group to be secure from attack, he has get out from behind enemy lines. If he doesn’t, it becomes black’s game to win. With this in mind, your move wasn’t a “non-threatening attack”, but a good move instead =).
